LEXSense.DefinitionShort: (a figurative extension of meaning of θριαμβεύω ‘to lead prisoners of war in a victory procession,’ not occurring in the NT) to demonstrate one’s successful conquest of opposition
LEXSense.Comments: Since the leading of prisoners of war in a victory procession is at the present time a relatively rare cultural phenomenon, it may be impossible to employ such a literal rendering of θριαμβεύω. One may, however, wish to employ a marginal note to indicate the background meaning of θριαμβεύω in this context.

LEXSense.DefinitionShort: to cause someone to completely triumph over
LEXSense.Comments: In a number of languages it is difficult to speak of triumphing without indicating the goal of such an event, but in {S:04700201400014} there is no specified object over which triumph occurs. It is possible to introduce Satan as the one over whom the believer is victorious (see {S:04700201100000}). However, it is also possible to understand θριαμβεύω in {S:04700201400014} as being essentially similar in meaning to {L:θριαμβεύω<SDBG:θριαμβεύω:000000>}[a] ({D:39.59}) and thus to translate {S:04700201400014} as ‘for in union with Christ we are always led by God as prisoners in Christ’s victorious procession.’
